description: {"blocks":[{"key":"alnh5","text":"Previous studies using confocal fluorescence microscopy and cryo-electron microscopy reported that most pathogenic LRRK2 mutants, as well as pharmacological inhibition of LRRK2 kinase activity with Type-I inhibitors, cause relocalization of LRRK2 to filamentous structures that colocalize with microtubules (PMID: 22080837; PMID: 28453723; PMID: 32783917; PMID: 32814344). Here we describe our confocal immunofluorescence microscopy method for measuring LRRK2 association with microtubules in a cell-based assay. This method can be used to screen the impact that LRRK2 mutations have on LRRK2 microtubule binding, as well as the effect of any compound on LRRK2 association with microtubules.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

1: Type I LRRK2 inhibitor MLi-2 enhances LRRK2 filament formation. FLAG-LRRK2 wildtype was transiently expressed in HEK293 cells for 24 hours (for immunoblotting analysis) or 48 hours (for immunofluorescence microscopy analysis). 3 hours prior to lysis or fixation, cells were treated with 100 nM MLi-2 or 0.1% (v/v) DMSO (control vehicle). For immunofluorescence analysis (left panel), cells were fixed with 4% PFA and stained with anti-FLAG (raised in mouse) and anti-tubulin (raised in rabbit) primary antibodies, followed by incubation with anti-mouse Alexa Fluor 488 and anti-rabbit Alexa Fluor 594 secondary antibodies. For immunoblotting analysis cells were harvested in complete lysis buffer and samples subjected to SDS-PAGE and western blotting. Membranes were probed with the indicated antibodies and were developed using the LI-COR Odyssey CLx Western Blot imaging system (right panel).","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}},"mime":"image/png","original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gsxfbn3x7.jpg","source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gsxdbn3x7.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gsxebn3x7.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gsxcbn3x7.webp","width":550}}}}

Add DAPI at   final concentration to the secondary antibody solution.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":197,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6gbiu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"1","error":false,"guid":"81BDFC30956511ECB01E39CF220385DE","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":1809}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1bgj1","text":"Incubate the samples with the secondary antibodies and DAPI at   for   in the dark.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":63,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":69,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"41co0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"9AB08D20956511ECB01E39CF220385DE","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"37","unit":32}},"1":{"type":"duration","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"duration":3600,"guid":"9EA91780956511ECB01E39CF220385DE","id":0,"label":"","pause":null,"preset":[],"start":null}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6jj8g","text":"Wash the samples 3 times with 0.2% (w/v) BSA in PBS (10 minutes per wash).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9imqo","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"1jnml","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":36}],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":6,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"63pvg","text":"Note: Samples can be kept in PBS at   for up to 2-3 weeks before proceeding to imaging.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"B4417C819AD311ECBB2C0A58A9FEAC02","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"4","unit":10},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"temperature"}}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1fgo5","text":"Image cells using a Zeiss LSM 710 or 880 laser scanning microscopes using the x40 EC Plan-Neofluar (NA 1.3) objective with a zoom of 0.6 and optical section thickness of 1.0 mm (image size 2048x2048 pixels, pixel size 0.173 μm).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"fvuov","text":"Image 50-100 cells from 4-6 randomly selected fields with Alexa Fluor 488-positive cells for each well (These are cells successfully transfected with Flag-LRRK2). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1qla0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6ojkd","text":"Perform cell counting using the Image J Cell Counter feature.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4nljs","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"358ma","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"sake","text":"Note: ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":70,"offset":207,"style":"bold"}],"key":"9kg4e","text":"Cell counting should be performed blinded to LRRK2 variant and treatment condition. For this purpose, randomised file names for the image files can be generated using a Python code script as detailed below (How to generate a Python code script to generate randomised file names).","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"21d7a","text":"Cells can be divided into 3 categories based on their Alexa Fluor 488 signal (corresponding to LRRK2 staining): ","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7u282","text":"     1. cells showing filamentous/string-like staining (“filamentous”); ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6plnr","text":"     2. cells with no filamentous staining but containing punctate/aggresome-like staining    (“punctate”);  ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"c7r2r","text":"    3. cells with only cytosolic staining (“cytosolic”). ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"p9vd","text":"For each experimental condition, count cells in each category.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"e34im","text":"DAPI and β-tubulin staining is used to ensure only cells containing a single nucleus are counted, avoiding cells that have not finished dividing or are multi-nuclear. ","type":"unordered-list-item"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6pgmj","text":"Once cell counting is done, data is unblinded and analysed as percentage of cells for each category using GraphPad Prism and applying a 2-way ANOVA and the post-hoc Dunnett’s test to evaluate statistical significance between different experimental conditions.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
